report_title: Dental Clinical Instrument Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: The Dental Clinical Instrument Manufacturing industry has declined slightly over the past five years despite stable demand for routine dental procedures and the growing number of Americans over the age of 65. Recent disruptions to the international market for US-made dental instruments have led to a significant decline in the value of industry exports over the five years to 2023. In addition, technological advancements have enabled manufacturers to produce dental instruments at a lower cost, bringing down industry prices and ultimately revenue. Over the past five years, revenue has slumped at a CAGR of 0.3% to $5.3 billion, including an expected 1.3% decline in 2023. Profit is expected to climb to 8.1% of revenue in 2023 from 7.7% in 2018.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Pandemic Negatively Affected Industry Demand and Revenue
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic caused a surge in unemployment as businesses were forced to shut down or limit operations. With higher unemployment, many people lost their employer-sponsored health insurance. The pandemic made it difficult for dentists and orthodontists to perform dental procedures safely, reducing downstream demand in 2020.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Increased Disposable Income and Manufacturers Reducing Operating Costs Boosted Profit
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The aging US population has limited the declining demand experienced by the industry because people over the age of 65 typically have higher levels of disposable income and health insurance coverage and are also more likely to require routine dental services. Over the past five years, the number of adults aged 65 and older has increased. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) freed up more consumer disposable income to be used on dental procedures. A significant share of this out-of-pocket cash was spent on preventative procedures. Over the past five years, demand from cosmetic dentists declined limiting elective and cosmetic procedures. Many of the products used in these procedures are advanced and costly to produce, so many manufacturers invested in research and development to find ways to reduce operating costs, ultimately boosting profit.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Industry Revenue is Expected to Decline Despite the Improving Economic Climate
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Several favorable demographic trends among US consumers will help increase demand for newly manufactured dental clinical instruments. Necessary trips to the dentist from the aging US population will limit revenue declines over the next five years. In addition, the industry will encounter increased demand from the generally improving economic climate and its effect on personal disposable income, as well as the number of people that can afford private health insurance. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act's (PPACA) mandated extension of covered oral care to all pediatric patients is expected to decrease the number of children without dental insurance.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Advanced and Specialized Equipment Will Boost Profitability and Contribute to Export Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The high-tech dental instruments and equipment market is growing faster than the overall dental instrument market. This trend is expected to continue over the next five years and will help limit revenue declines. High-value, high-profit clinical instruments used in specialized dental procedures such as preventative dental care or cosmetic dentistry will boost industry-wide profit. Developing advanced and specialized equipment is expected to support demand for US-made products in export markets. However, overseas competition will continue to keep exports low, despite the projected depreciation of the US dollar, making US goods relatively less expensive.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Manufacturers Will Increasingly Produce Specialized Instruments Reducing Reliance on Low-Skilled Production Workers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As manufacturers increasingly produce high-end, specialized clinical instruments over the next five years, companies will continue to focus on maintaining their most highly skilled, highly trained research and development employees. Increased production and automation is expected to reduce reliance on low-skilled production line workers. The relative importance of product development engineers and designers will continue to expand over the next five years. Competition among the industry's largest manufacturers will likely continue to result in acquisition activity, with many of these small companies being acquired for their innovative technologies or geographic market share.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures tools and other instruments used in clinical practices by dentist offices and dental laboratories. These include diagnostic and procedural tools, cements and other impression materials, instrument

mixed_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: medium - steady

key_trends: The aging of the US population has contributed to increased demand
Falling demand from overseas has hurt industry companies
Many domestic operators have refocused on the domestic market
Companies will focus on maintaining their highly trained R&D employees
High-value, high-margin clinical instruments will boost industry-wide profit
The improving economic climate and aging US population will continue to boost revenue
New product development will likely set the pace for growth over the next five years

market_segmentation.segment_description: Dental clinics are the largest market for manufacturers accounting for almost one-half of revenue and are the primary market that dental instrument wholesalers target.
Manufacturers rely on wholesalers to distribute a significant portion of dental instruments that they manufacture.
Dental laboratories comprise the smallest market for dental clinical instrument manufacturers.

products_and_services.product_description: Diagnostic, imaging and procedural instruments comprise the largest segment of revenue in 2023.
Orthodontic instruments include various end cutters, wire cutters and pliers, as well as band pushers and ligature directors.
Storage and cleaning systems comprise the smallest product segment in the industry in 2023.
A dental impression is an imprint of hard teeth (and sometimes surrounding tissue) used for making dentures and plastic models and consulting with patients.

Implants comprise the second-largest segment of revenue in 2023. Dental implants are typically made from titanium and are placed in such a way as to resemble an actual tooth (i.e. they are placed within the bone).
Dental laboratory equipment includes machines, tools and devices used to craft custom-made bridges, crowns, implants, veneers, dentures and other dental and orthodontic devices.

tier_1_suppliers: Plastic Products Miscellaneous Manufacturing in the US
Iron & Steel Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Plastic & Resin Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The rapid pace of technological change in the dental clinical instrument manufacturing industry drives demand for its products.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Number of Adults Over the Age of 65
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The number of adults over the age of 65 and the median age of the population in general, drive demand for products.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports have grown to satisfy a greater share of domestic demand despite trade being disrupted due to the pandemic.
The US dollar has strengthened over the past five years, resulting in exports becoming increasingly expensive for foreign markets.
Canada is the largest exporting partner for domestic dental clinical instrument manufacturers.

business_locations.location_description: The West region has the largest concentration of manufacturers.
The Southeast region has the second-largest concentration of manufacturers.
The Mid-Atlantic region has the third-largest concentration of manufacturers.
The Great Lakes region has a significant presence of manufacturers.
The Southwest region has a small concentration of manufacturers.
The Rocky Mountains have a small concentration of manufacturers.
New England has a small concentration of manufacturers.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE US FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION (FDA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The FDA classifies medical devices as class I, II or III depending on the degree of control necessary.
Compliance with FDA regulations requires compliance with corresponding state regulations.

regulations_points.regulation_title: AMALGAMS (ALLOYS OF MERCURY WITH VARIOUS METALS) USED FOR DENTAL FILLINGS ARE AN AREA OF CONTENTION
regulations_points.regulation_description: Critics have argued that the mercury contained in amalgams is harmful to human health.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, increasing barriers to entry.
The industry has high revenue volatility, increasing barriers.
There is no industry assistance, keeping barriers steady.

basis_points.basis_description: Competition is high and based on product innovation and quality.
Manufacturers compete to develop innovative products for efficiency.
Manufacturers must compete to develop relationships with wholesalers.
Manufacturers must compete with imports satisfying domestic demand.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry exhibits a medium level of concentration.
The two largest manufacturers account for almost half of revenue.
Small private manufacturers with specialized expertise make up the rest.
Larger manufacturers acquire smaller ones to increase products and share.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit climbs as manufacturers benefit from lower input costs and custom dental tools with higher profit margins
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, will account for an estimated 8.1% of revenue in 2023.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages jump as manufacturers maintain highly trained and knowledgeable employees
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wage expenses are expected to account for 22.8% of revenue in 2023.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase costs decline due to lower steel prices
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs are expected to account for 29.0% of revenue in 2023.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Dental Clinical Instrument Manufacturing industry exhibits a low level of capital intensity.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry has exhibited a high level of revenue volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The pandemic resulted in a massive decline in revenue
volatility_points.volatility_description: Some of the industry's products associated with discretionary services, like teeth whitening, typically experience decreased demand during economic.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The Dental Clinical Instrument Manufacturing industry experiences a moderate threat from technological disruption.
The Dental Clinical Instrument Manufacturing industry has a high level of technological change.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by rising imports from abroad?
FAQs.answer: Imports account for a moderate portion of domestic demand for dental instruments.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Many dental manufacturers also produce products for other healthcare industries.
